docs.snippet: A Government spokesman said today that the United States was relieved by the terms of an accord struck Friday by 11 Latin American debtor nations. But other experts cautioned that the agreement would move the countries closer to formation of a cartel...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Government spokesman said today that the United States was relieved by the terms of an accord struck Friday by 11 Latin American debtor nations. But other experts cautioned that the agreement would move the countries closer to formation of a cartel if their loan burden worsened. The 11 countries concluded a two-day meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, with a statement calling for more lenient terms for their loan payments and setting up regular meetings. The next is to be in Buenos Aires in September.

headline.main: DEBT TALKS DRAW A MIXED REACTION

docs.snippet: A growing number of Latin American nations have enacted laws requiring journalists to get government licenses before they can go to work, a trend that publishers and editors in the hemisphere are trying to stop because they say the laws imperil press...
docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of Latin American nations have enacted laws requiring journalists to get government licenses before they can go to work, a trend that publishers and editors in the hemisphere are trying to stop because they say the laws imperil press freedom. Bolivian publishers are campaigning to overturn a licensing measure that took effect last month. Six newspapers in the Dominican Republic have gone to court to fight a licensing law enacted earlier this year. A reporter from the United States, prosecuted for working without a license as a journalist for papers in Costa Rica, is challenging that country's five-year-old licensing law before an international commission in Washington. Licensing and Control ''In licensing lies control, and a controlled press is not - for it cannot be - independent and free,'' the American Society of Newspaper Editors said in a recent bulletin about the case in Costa Rica.

headline.main: LICENSING OF LATIN JOURNALISTS GIVES RISE TO GROWING FEARS

docs.snippet: The Inter-American Press Association asked President Alfredo Stroessner on Friday to lift the three- month-old suspension of the nation's largest daily newspaper, ABC Color, and was told the request would be considered.   The press association...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Inter-American Press Association asked President Alfredo Stroessner on Friday to lift the three- month-old suspension of the nation's largest daily newspaper, ABC Color, and was told the request would be considered. The press association president, Horacio Aguirre, director of Las Americas of Miami, said the request was made both orally and in writing at a cordial 40-minute meeting with General Stroessner, who has ruled this nation since he took power in a military coup in May 1954. Also attending the meeting was Edward Seaton of Seaton Publications in Manhattan, Kan., vice president of the press association's executive committee, which is on a five-day visit to Paraguay and Uruguay to study restrictions on press freedom. The committee is accompanied by a former president of the group, George Beebe of The Miami Herald; Charles Scripps of the Scripps- Howard Newspapers Group, and Andres Garcia Lavin of Novedades de Yucatan of Merida, Yucatan, Mexico.

headline.main: PRESS UNIT PLEA ON PARAGUAY BAN

docs.snippet: Although he was sitting in a Uruguayan military jail this weekend, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, a leading presidential candidate, appeared to be just where he wanted to be - riding a surge of popularity. But aggressive maneuvering by him and other...
docs.lead_paragraph: Although he was sitting in a Uruguayan military jail this weekend, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, a leading presidential candidate, appeared to be just where he wanted to be - riding a surge of popularity. But aggressive maneuvering by him and other civilian presidential aspirants, and by the country's military rulers, may upset prospects for Uruguay's first presidential election since 1971. The military, which seized power 11 years ago, has tired of taking the blame for economic disasters it has been unable to bring under control. Most of the generals have been looking for a safe way to unload their responsibilities without being placed on trial for human rights violations, as happened to former junta members in neighboring Argentina after that country returned to democracy last year.

headline.main: IS THERE A SAFE WAY OUT FOR THE URUGUAYAN MILITARY?

docs.snippet: For Eduardo Wiesner Duran, an economist and politician who is now an international civil servant, these are not easy times.     He has been director of the Western Hemisphere department at the International Monetary Fund for the past 18 months. It...
docs.lead_paragraph: For Eduardo Wiesner Duran, an economist and politician who is now an international civil servant, these are not easy times. He has been director of the Western Hemisphere department at the International Monetary Fund for the past 18 months. It would be a sensitive and trying job for anyone, but doubly so for a Latin American. Last week at a meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, Argentina was named to coordinate the negotiating position of itself and 10 other Latin American nations on future debt discussions with international agencies, including the I.M.F. The group owes an estimated $350 billion, with three of its members - Argentina, Brazil and Mexico - owing about $290 billion of that.

docs.snippet: General Strike Brings Montevideo to a Halt    MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 27 (AP) - The Uruguayan capital was viritually paralyzed today by a a general strike on the 11th anniversary of the coup that brought the military regime to power.   Most...
docs.lead_paragraph: General Strike Brings Montevideo to a Halt MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 27 (AP) - The Uruguayan capital was viritually paralyzed today by a a general strike on the 11th anniversary of the coup that brought the military regime to power. Most factories, stores and private offices were shut.

docs.snippet: The United States Olympic basketball team was placed in Group B, considered the weaker   bracket, at the draw for opening-round games Friday for the 1984 Summer Olympics at Los Angeles.  Heavily favored to win the gold medal with the boycott of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Olympic basketball team was placed in Group B, considered the weaker bracket, at the draw for opening-round games Friday for the 1984 Summer Olympics at Los Angeles. Heavily favored to win the gold medal with the boycott of the Soviet Union, the American team was put in a group that also included China, Canada, Uruguay, France and Spain.

docs.snippet: A new Reagan Administration report on Nicaragua accuses the Sandinistas of continuing to promote subversion in Central America, but concludes that military support to guerrillas in El Salvador has been sporadic since 1981.    Draft copies of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: A new Reagan Administration report on Nicaragua accuses the Sandinistas of continuing to promote subversion in Central America, but concludes that military support to guerrillas in El Salvador has been sporadic since 1981. Draft copies of the report, which State Department officials said would be made public next week without substantial revision, were sent to members of Congress today. The 35-page report, titled ''Background Paper: Nicaragua's Military Buildup and Support for Central American Subversion,'' was prepared jointly by the State Department and the Defense Department. It is the third report on Soviet, Cuban and Nicaraguan activities in Central America prepared by the Administration for public dissemination since 1981. It is intended, according to Administration officials, to assuage Congressional and public doubts about Administration contentions that Nicaragua has played a major role in trying to destabilize neighboring countries, particularly El Salvador.

headline.main: AID TO SALVADOR REBELS IS SPORADIC, U.S. SAYS

docs.snippet: A glance at the world on the 208th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence is not reassuring about the condition of liberty or democracy.    More nations have ''proclaimed liberty'' in the last 40 years, as the 13 American states did on July...
docs.lead_paragraph: A glance at the world on the 208th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence is not reassuring about the condition of liberty or democracy. More nations have ''proclaimed liberty'' in the last 40 years, as the 13 American states did on July 4, 1776, than ever before, but comparatively few have followed it, and even the American people, now spread over a vast continent and beyond, are still arguing about what it means. Freedom House, the New York City organization that has been trying to monitor the state of human rights and civil liberties in the world for the last 11 years, notes some progress but little change in the last decade. In what it concedes is a difficult and controversial measuring process, it lists 52 countries as now ''free,'' the same as its calculation in 1973, 56 nations now ''partly free,'' as compared with 39 11 years ago, and 58 ''not free,'' as compared with 70 in its estimate of 1973.

headline.main: WASHINGTON The World On the Fourth

docs.snippet: Brazil's Opening, Uruguay's Retreat It's not just size that distinguishes Brazil from its neighbor Uruguay. Both nations are outwardly moving from military to civilian rule. But Brazil's motion is real. Uruguay's is stalled because its armed forces...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil's Opening, Uruguay's Retreat It's not just size that distinguishes Brazil from its neighbor Uruguay. Both nations are outwardly moving from military to civilian rule. But Brazil's motion is real. Uruguay's is stalled because its armed forces treat democratic opponents as subversive criminals.
